qas.question: What was a subject that Avicenna studied, but did not develop a theory on?
Who expanded on Avicenna's work in temporal logic?
What became the dominant system of Islamic logic?
What European logician was greatly influenced by Avicenna?
Whose law of noncontradiction did Avicenna endorse?
who studied and developed theories on temporal logic?
Who's system of logic did Avicenna further develop?
Who's system of logic is dominant in modern times?

plausible_answers.text: Albertus Magnus and William of Ockham.

qas.question: What European logicians did Avicennian logic borrow from?
What was a subject that Avicenna studied, and developed a theory on?
Who expanded on Avicenna's work in permanent logic?
What became the nondominant system of Islamic logic?
What European magician was greatly influenced by Avicenna?
Whose law of contradiction did Avicenna endorse?

context: An early formal system of <a0_0><b10_0>temporal logic<b10_0/><a0_0/> was studied by <b5_0>Avicenna<b5_0/>. Although he did not develop a real theory of temporal propositions, he did study the relationship between temporalis and the implication. Avicenna's work was further developed by <a1_0><b6_0><b7_0><b11_0>Najm al-Dīn al-Qazwīnī al-Kātibī<b11_0/><b7_0/><b6_0/><a1_0/> and became the dominant system of Islamic logic until modern times. <a2_0><b12_0>Avicennian logic<b12_0/><a2_0/> also influenced several early European logicians such as <a3_0><b8_0><b13_0>Albertus Magnus<b13_0/><a3_0/> and William of Ockham.<b8_0/> <b9_0>Avicenna<b9_0/> endorsed the law of noncontradiction proposed by <a4_0><b14_0>Aristotle<b14_0/><a4_0/>, that a fact could not be both true and false at the same time and in the same sense of the terminology used. He stated, "Anyone who denies the law of noncontradiction should be beaten and burned until he admits that to be beaten is not the same as not to be beaten, and to be burned is not the same as not to be burned."
